section.title: Final moments of Fujarski Showdown
section.about: Tadeusz Fujarski ściga się z Krzysztofem Tatarskim po tym jak jego ojciec - Bogdan Fujarski - oferuje mu pełny bak jeśli wygra wyścig z E34. Wszyscy jednak spodziewali się spotkać ojca Tadka, który w swoim czasie był legendarnym kierowcą Fiata 125p. Krążą pogłoski, że Bogdan ścigał się kiedyś w Stratopolonezie, czyli Polonezem z silnikiem Lancii Stratos (a tak naprawdę z Ferrari Dino) z tyłu. Jego koledzy zaskoczeni przybyciem Tadeusza są na niego wściekli za to, że on przyjechał zamiast jego ojca, ale on ich uspokaja mówiąc, że dostarcza pierogi na tej przełęczy już od 5 lat. Oni zaskoczeni tym faktem życzą mu powodzenia w wyścigu. Tuż przed wyścigiem poznaje się ze swoim rywalem:

section.title: What is Touge?
section.about: Chinese character 峠 touge means literally mountain road or pass. Because of Japans unique geography consisting of islands nearly 73% of land is mountainius and rugged. Because of this the majority of roads in japans consists of sharp turn and hairpins to reduce the difference in altitude needed to climb these roads. This results in less wear on cars and increased safety due to lower speed but ironically creates the perfect scenario for enthusiast to race on.

person.name: Kunimitsu Takahashi
person.about: Japanese, motorcycling legend, was the foremost creator of drifting techniques in the 1970s. His legacy popularized the sport and give rise to many 走り屋 hashirya, japanese street racers.

person.name: Keiichi Tsuchiya
person.about: Became particularly interested by Takahashi’s early drift techniques and began honing his drifting skills on these same mountain roads and quickly gained a reputation amongst the racing crowd as he took them to the next level. In 1987, several popular car magazines and tuning garages agreed to produce a video of Tsuchiya’s drifting skills in his Toyota AE86 (Corolla). The grainy low budget video, known as Pluspy, became an international hit and inspired many of the professional drifting drivers on the circuits today. Because of his flashy and fast driving Keiichi is known as the ドリフト キング - drift king.

section.title: Cars
section.about:
Unlike straight line racing where a lot depends on outright power, in Touge racing, other performance aspects will set your car apart, especially handling and weight distribution.
For instance, a small, tossable car like the Toyota MR2, prone to snap-oversteer, can beat a stock Mercedes AMG GT-R on a Touge course with the proper tuning. The same is true for other smaller cars such as the ever-popular AE86 and Honda S2000. Here are examples of few iconic Touge cars.
